statement.tex: %text Solve the differential equation \[ \qquad \cos^2 x\cdot \frac{dy}{dx} + y = \tan x \] %

options.tex: %text \[\cos^2 x\cdot \frac{dy}{dx} + y = \tan x \] is a \underline\text{linear differential equation} %
%text \[\cos^2 x\cdot \frac{dy}{dx} + y = \tan x \] is of the form \[ \frac{dy}{dx} = F \left(\frac{y}{x}\right) \]. Therefore, it is a \underline\text{homogeneous differential equation} %

reason.tex:
%text In a linear differential equation \[ \qquad \dfrac{dy}{dx} + P(x)\cdot y = Q(x) \]
the integrating factor is given by \[ e^{\int P(x)\cdot dx} \] In this case, that would be \[ e^{\int \sec^2\cdot dx} = e^{\tan x} \]
Notice that when we \underline\text{multiply both sides} by the integrating factor, then
% \begin{align} e^{\tan x}\dfrac{dy}{dx} + e^{\tan x}\sec^2 x\cdot y &= e^{\tan x}\tan x\cdot\sec^2 x \\ \implies \dfrac{d}{dx}\left(e^{\tan x}\cdot y\right) &= e^{\tan x}\tan x\cdot\sec^2 x \end{align}

\begin{align} \frac{d}{dx}\left(e^{\tan x}\cdot y\right) &= e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x\cdot \tan x \\ \implies e^{\tan x} y &= \int e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x\cdot \tan x \cdot dx \end{align} %text
The above is pretty straight forward.
We need to now think about solving \[ \qquad \int e^{\tan x}\cdot \sec^2 x\cdot \tan x \cdot dx \]
Now, if \[ z = \tan x \], then \[ dz = \sec^2 x \cdot dx \] And therefore
% \begin{align} \int e^{\tan x}\cdot \sec^2 x\cdot \tan x \cdot dx &= \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz \end{align}

\begin{align} \int e^zz\cdot dz &= \underbrace{z\int e^z\cdot dz - \int\left[ \frac{d}{dz}z\int e^z\cdot dz \right]dz}_{\text{Integration by parts}}\\ &= z\cdot e^z - \int \left(\int e^z\cdot dz\right)\cdot dz \\ &= z\cdot e^z - \int e^z\cdot dz = (z-1)\cdot e^z + C \\ &= \underbrace{(\tan x - 1)\cdot e^{\tan x}}_{z = \tan x} + C \\ \end{align} %text
And given that \[ e^{\tan x}\cdot y = \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz = (\tan x - 1)\cdot e^{\tan x} + C\] we can say that \[ \qquad y = (\tan x - 1) + \frac{C}{e^{\tan x}} \] %
